storyContent.tagHTML: Early Ächäryas of Digambar and Shvetämbar Traditions

The writings of Ächärya Kundkund, from around 2000 years ago, are revered by all Digambars. One of the most ancient scriptures accepted by the Digambar tradition is the Shatakhandägam by Ächärya Pushpadanta and Bhutabali. A key text accepted by both Shvetämbar and Digambar traditions is the Tattvärtha-sutra by Umäsväti (also known as Umäsvämi).

Later, in the 5th or 6th century, Ächärya Siddhasen Diwäkar wrote the influential Sanmati-Tarka. During the 8th century, Ächärya Haribhadra-suri composed many works, including the Shad-darshan Samuchchaya. By this time, idol worship was well established, which led to the rise of renegade monks in the Shvetämbar sect known as Yatis or Chaityaväsis, who lived comfortably in temples. Haribhadra-suri was the first to criticize their excesses.

Major narrative works like the Mahä-Purän by Digambar Ächärya Jinsen and the Trishashti Shaläkä Purush by Hemchandra-ächärya documented the lives of great Jain personalities. Efforts to reform the Yatis were made by Vardhamänsuri and his successor Jindatta-suri, who founded the Kharatar Gachchha (Purer Sect) around 1150. In the 16th century, the famous Ächärya Hirvijay-suri impressed the Mughal emperor Akbar, persuading him to forbid animal slaughter on certain days. Later, the mystic poet Yogi Änandghanji wrote the beloved Änandghanji Chovisi, a collection of devotional songs.

Shri Känji Swämi (1889-1980 A.D.) was born a Shvetämbar Sthänakaväsi and became a monk at an early age. His life changed when, at age 30, he studied Kundkund's Samaysär. He was so moved that he dedicated his life to giving discourses on it. At age 45, he left the Sthänakaväsi order to become a Digambar layman (Shrävak), though he never took formal Digambar initiation.

His greatest achievement was revolutionizing the study of scriptures, encouraging every householder, especially the educated, to engage directly with difficult texts. He gave prominence to the Nishchay Naya (absolute point of view) over the Vyavahär Naya (practical point of view), stressing inward thought over external rituals. His movement attracted many followers and he is credited with the consecration ceremonies of about 95 temples.

events.title: Kundkund's Philosophy
events.description: Ächärya Kundkund writes his revered works, including Samaysär, laying a foundation for Digambar philosophy.

events.title: The Universal Scripture
events.description: Umäsväti (Umäsvämi) composes the Tattvärtha-sutra, a text uniquely accepted by both Digambar and Shvetämbar traditions.

events.title: Rise of the Yatis
events.description: The establishment of idol worship leads to the rise of Chaityaväsis or Yatis, monks living in temples. Ächärya Haribhadra-suri is the first to criticize their lax conduct.

events.title: Great Biographies
events.description: Ächärya Jinsen (Digambar) and Hemchandra-ächärya (Shvetämbar) compose voluminous works on the lives of Tirthankars and other great figures.

events.title: The Kharatar Gachchha
events.description: Jindatta-suri, popularly known as Dada Gurudev, founds the Kharatar Gachchha (Purer Sect) around 1150 in an effort to reform the excesses of the Yatis.

events.title: An Emperor's Edict
events.description: Ächärya Hirvijay-suri of the 16th century impresses the Mughal emperor Akbar, who issues an order forbidding animal slaughter on certain days.

events.title: Discovery of Samaysär
events.description: Känji Swämi, a Sthänakaväsi monk, studies Ächärya Kundkund's Samaysär and is profoundly transformed.

events.title: A New Path
events.description: At age 45, he leaves his order to become a Digambar layman, dedicating his life to giving discourses on Kundkund's philosophy.

events.title: The Känji-Swämi Movement
events.description: His movement emphasizes inward thought (Nishchay Naya) and direct study of scriptures by laypeople, attracting a large following.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Kundkund
charactersData.description: An ancient and highly revered Ächärya (~1st century A.D.) whose writings, especially the Samaysär, form a cornerstone of Digambar philosophy.

charactersData.name: Umäsväti / Umäsvämi
charactersData.description: The author of the Tattvärtha-sutra, a uniquely authoritative scripture that is accepted and studied by both the Shvetämbar and Digambar traditions.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Haribhadra-suri
charactersData.description: A prolific 8th-century writer and the first major figure to criticize the lax practices of the Chaityaväsis or Yatis.

charactersData.name: Hirvijay-suri
charactersData.description: A renowned 16th-century Ächärya who successfully persuaded the Mughal emperor Akbar to issue proclamations restricting animal slaughter.

charactersData.name: Yogi Änandghanji
charactersData.description: A mystic poet monk whose collection of 24 devotional songs, the 'Änandghanji Chovisi', is one of the most beloved works of Jain devotional literature.

charactersData.name: Känji-Swämi
charactersData.description: A 20th-century reformer who, inspired by Kundkund's Samaysär, started a popular movement emphasizing direct study of scriptures and focusing on the absolute point of view (Nishchay Naya).

quizData.question: Which Ächärya's writings are so revered by Digambars that he is mentioned in their main blessing prayer?
What is the name of the scripture by Umäsväti that is uniquely accepted by both Shvetämbar and Digambar traditions?
Who was the first Ächärya to criticize the excesses of the Yatis or Chaityaväsis?
What were Yatis or Chaityaväsis?
quizData.answer: Renegade monks who lived comfortably in temples.

quizData.question: Which Ächärya founded the Kharatar Gachchha (Purer Sect) to reform the Yatis?
Which Mughal emperor was so impressed by Ächärya Hirvijay-suri that he forbade animal slaughter on certain days?
What is the name of the famous collection of 24 devotional songs written by Yogi Änandghanji?
By which tradition was Känji-Swämi born and initiated as a monk?
Which ancient scripture by Ächärya Kundkund profoundly influenced Känji-Swämi?
After being influenced by Kundkund's writings, what did Känji-Swämi decide to become at age 45?
Känji-Swämi's movement gave more prominence to which point of view: Nishchay Naya or Vyavahär Naya?
quizData.answer: Nishchay Naya (the absolute point of view).

quizData.question: What was the greatest achievement or revolution brought about by Känji-Swämi?
quizData.answer: Stimulating every householder to study the most difficult Jain scriptures for themselves.

quizData.question: What is the title of the ancient scripture written by Ächärya Pushpadanta and Bhutabali?
What is the name of the book by Ächärya Siddhasen Diwäkar, written during the time of King Vikramäditya?
What voluminous work by the Digambar Ächärya Jinsen deals with the lives of great Jain personalities?
What similar voluminous work was written by the Shvetämbar Hemchandra-ächärya?
What was the real name of the mystic poet popularly known as Änandghanji?
Who was a prolific writer, composing texts in Sanskrit, Präkrit, and an older form of Gujarati?
How many temples is Känji-Swämi given credit for consecrating (Panch Kalyänak Mahotsav)?
What does Känji-Swämi's movement stress: inward thought or external rituals?

graphicsData.title: Ancient Scriptures
graphicsData.description: The foundational texts of Jainism, like the Tattvärtha-sutra and Kundkund's Samaysär, were composed by great Ächäryas, preserving knowledge for millennia.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A collection of ancient-looking palm-leaf manuscripts and scrolls.

graphicsData.title: The Rise of the Yatis
graphicsData.description: As temples grew in prominence, a sect of monks known as Yatis or Chaityaväsis began to live comfortably within them, a practice criticized by reformers like Haribhadra-suri.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Monks depicted living in a lavishly decorated temple, contrary to ascetic principles.

graphicsData.title: A Royal Audience
graphicsData.description: The revered Ächärya Hirvijay-suri speaks with the powerful Mughal emperor Akbar, convincing him of the principle of non-violence (Ahimsä).
graphicsData.imageAlt: A Jain monk in simple robes having a serious discussion with a richly dressed emperor in his court.

graphicsData.title: The Mystic's Song
graphicsData.description: Yogi Änandghanji, absorbed in contemplation of the soul, composes his famous 'Chovisi,' a series of devotional songs praising the 24 Tirthankars.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A mystic monk sitting under a tree, lost in thought and song, with a simple instrument.

graphicsData.title: The Samaysär Revolution
graphicsData.description: Känji-Swämi delivers a powerful discourse on Kundkund's Samaysär, inspiring a movement for laypeople to study scriptures and focus on inner truth.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A 20th-century spiritual leader speaking passionately from a stage to a large audience of men and women.

graphicsData.title: A Bridge Between Traditions
graphicsData.description: A symbolic image representing the Shvetämbar and Digambar traditions, both of which revere the Tattvärtha-sutra by Umäsväti.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Two distinct paths converging on a single, central ancient book.
